awd_titl_txt: Upgrade of the Scanning Electron Microscope Lab at the Arizona LaserChron Center
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding to acquire three new instruments that will be used to determine the chemistry and structure of minerals which record a variety of geologic events and processes. The instruments will be utilized in the Arizona LaserChron Center (ALC), which is an NSF-supported community facility that supports research in Earth Sciences. Science questions addressed by ALC researchers focus on reconstructing the history of igneous activity (e.g., volcanic eruptions), formation of ore deposits, uplift of mountain ranges, accumulation of sediment and formation of associated hydrocarbon resources, evolutionary changes, early evolution of the Earth, Moon, meteorites, and Mars, history of Earth’s climate (e.g., patterns of ice sheets), and archaeological trade routes. The new instruments will be utilized to support the research of ~350 faculty members, professional geologists, and students per year. Supported activities include generating the images and analyses that are needed for NSF-funded projects, providing opportunities for researchers to learn the theory and methods of instrument operation, and offering educational and outreach activities for under-represented minority participants. 

The requested instruments consist of (1) an Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) detector, (2) an Electron Backscatter Diffraction (EBSD) detector, and (3) a Raman spectroscopic system. The EDS and EBSD detector systems will replace the outdated systems which were acquired with our Scanning Electronic Microscope (SEM) in 2009. These instruments, combined with the new “AZtec Live/HKL” software included with  the Instruments, will provide the chemical and structural information needed for ALC researchers to conduct cutting-edge research in geochronology, petrochronology, and thermochronology. New capabilities in microstructural analysis will also be enabled. The Raman system, combined with the “Correlate” software package offered by the manufacturer, will provide powerful new capabilities of chemical mapping and phase identification. Collectively, these enhanced capabilities will provide the images and analyses needed by ALC researchers more efficiently, at lower cost, and with enhanced resolution, and will also allow ALC researchers to explore exciting new science applications regarding: (1) the spatial context of in situ geochronometric minerals, (2) 4D evolution of shear zones, (3) use of baddeleyite for chronologic and chemical studies of mafic rocks, (4) processes of Pb loss in minerals, (5) provenance of detrital minerals, (6) many processes that control modal abundances, sizes, shapes, and orientations of minerals in various rock types, and (7) application of elastic thermobarometers to study a variety of geologic processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Following are four significant outcomes from this award:

1. This award provided the funding to acquire and deploy three new instruments, including (1) an EDAX Octane Elite Super EDS System, (2) an EDAX Velocity Super EBSD System, and (3) a Renishaw inVia Qontor confocal Raman Microspectral Imaging System. These instruments are part of the instrumental infrastructure within the Arizona LaserChron Center (ALC), which is an NSF EAR Community Facility that provides support for >350 researchers and students per year. The new instruments have helped us achieve the primary objectives of the ALC, which are to:

  • Generate U-Th-Pb ages, Hf isotope ratios, trace element concentrations, and SEM/Raman spectral information that is of optimal precision, accuracy, spatial resolution, and efficiency.
  • Provide opportunities for NSF-supported researchers to use our instruments and expertise to address geologic problems.
  • Drive the development of new techniques and applications.
  • Use every aspect of facility operation to increase access to geochronology and build diversity and expertise among geochronologists and users of geochronology.

Our new instruments have provided opportunities for ALC researchers and students to conduct research in eight different areas:

  • Providing the Microstructural and Textural Context for Geochronologic Minerals.
  • Developing Baddeleyite for Geochronology of Mafic Rocks.
  • Evaluating Radiation Damage and Pb-loss in Zircon.
  • Fingerprinting Zircon Sources.
  • Phase Mapping, Mineral Chemistry, and Grain Size/Shape/Orientation.
  • Applications to Petrology and Thermobarometry.
  • 4D Evolution of Shear Zones.
  • Characterization of Gems.

Figure 1 shows an example of the power of using Raman spectroscopic information to identify portions of crystals that have compromised age information.

2. Three ALC researchers have received exceptional training and professional development opportunities as a result of this award:

A. Dr. Zachary Michels participated in all aspects of this award, from proposal preparation (as a Co-investigator) through collaborating with a large number of researchers who used the instruments to generate data in support of their NSF-funded research projects. Dr. Michels has recently moved to a different academic institution, which is unfortunate for the ALC but an excellent contribution for the broader community.

B. Tristan Nolan used the instruments as an undergraduate researcher prior to graduating during Spring 2023. With the departure of Dr. Michels, Tristan has become the manager of our SEM/Raman lab. He is on track to become a member of the next generation of instrumentalists. 

C. Oddisey Knox also worked in the SEM lab with Dr. Michels as an undergraduate student. She has since completed her BS degree and become an ALC researcher. Given that Oddisey is multi-racial, and a military veteran, she serves as an excellent role model for our student visitors, many of whom are from under-represented and under-served groups.

3. New methods that take full advantage of the new EDS/EBSD/Raman instruments and that were not previously available at the University of Arizona and the Arizona LaserChron Center, have been implemented and continue to be streamlined. These new methods are significantly impacting the science conducted by ALC collaborators, and have considerably expanded the opportunities for student training in cutting-edge analytical methods the ALC can provide.

4. Our new instruments have already provided research and training opportunities for a large number of faculty members and students. During the award period our new instruments supported the research of 17 faculty members and research scientists, 3 post-doctoral scholars, 16 graduate students, and 8 undergraduate students. These researchers conducted research in support of 15 different NSF awards. The instruments have also been utilized during a variety of training and outreach activities. Figure 2 shows an example of using our SEM system for an outreach activity involving MIddle School students.
